In my target runtime workbench I have two projects, one with mainly .logic files
and a .java file, and another project which is a java eclipse plug-in project.
When I edit a .logic file, close the workbench, and choose to save the changes
to the editor, I get a building workspace pop-up followed by an NPE in my .log file.

Philippe, what should we do here - looks like the Java builder is initializing 
a container, after the contributor has been shutdown?
This is similar to bug 66303, and could be addressed.
*** Bug 66662 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Ping Philippe for RC3 approval

+1 for RC3. I find it weird that we are still getting notifications during 
shutdown (it isn't the builder triggering init).

This bug has a similar flavour to bug 55242. The problem is that plugin A is 
activating plugin B after B has been shutdown. A is activating B since B 
provides an extension for an extension point that A defines (and A is 
instantiating/calling the extension implementation). A more encompassing fix 
would be to have plug-in A guard against calling extensions in plug-ins that 
have been shutdown (which we are investigating in bug 55242).

This would mean the fix would be in JCORE - avoid calling initializers in 
upstream, shut-down plugins.

Created an attachment (id=12273)
patch

(Meanwhile, here's a localized fix for the JRE container and variable
initializers. The patch ensures the plug-in is active before continuing with
initialization. However, this feels like the wrong fix).

Pascal, this is a similar problem to bug 55242. Please advise if there is a 
general solution to the problem of accessing extensions in shutdown plug-ins. 
This feels like a problem that exists everywhere.

Exactly, I would expect #createExecutableExtension to throw the CoreException 
in this scenario. Clients are already checking for these and react 
appropriately in general.

I agree with Philippe, this would fix the problem in general (except for 
clients that re-use previously instantiated delegates - however, the Java 
model is creating new delegates each time).

After thinking about it, throwing the exception is not the answer because when
the system is shutting down some people want to createExecutableExtension and it
would then break their code.
Of course they should protect themselves from exceptions but it would still be a
big change in the behavior.

We are looking into the addition of a method to test if the framework is stopping.

moving to Equinox and assigning to Pascal.  

Tom, please attach a patch for the framework stopping flag.

Pascal, please attach a patch with behaviour something like...

In the eclipse adaptor we need to expose something that we can ask the 
question "has bundle X already been shutdown (as the result of a system 
shutdown)".  If it has, then createExecutableExtension should throw a 
CoreException.  This new mechanism should be controlled by a sytem property (of 
course) called "eclipse.strictShutdown".  By default this value is true (or not 
set).  if it is set to "false" then createExecutableExtension should skip the 
shutdown test and go ahead as normal (i.e., attempt to create the extension)

While this is not an API change in anyway (createEE is already spec'd to throw  
CoreException), it is a change in behaviour.  The new behaviour is much safer 
and more logical.  However, there may be cases where existing plugins have been 
successfully shutting down without receiving any exceptions.

Created an attachment (id=12311)
Patch to set System Bundle STOPPING state correctly

Patch to set the System Bundle state to STOPPING at the correct time in the
shutdown process.  It must be the first thing done in the shutdown process.

Re: comment#12, doesn't this mean Jeff that all plugins would then still need 
to protect against calling extensions of shutdown plugins, in case the strict 
mode is off ?

Patches reviewed by DJ, Jeff and I.
Released in HEAD.
Will be in > 200406162000.

plugins already have to catch CoreException.  If strict mode is ON, this 
exceptoin will be more popular.
Problems have been discovered.
*** Bug 67613 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 67625 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Although not functionnal problems, the problems that occurend were captured in
the bugs that have been marked as dup.

As a result of that and complementary discussions we slightly changed the story.
A ClassNotFoundException is now being thrown if the class being loaded belongs
to a plugin that has already been shutdown. This exception is then caught by
createExecutableExtension that wraps it into a CoreException.

Note that this new behavior is more permissive and more correct in regard to
activation since plugins can now be activated while shutting down the platform
Of course we don't reactivate plugin that have already been shutdown while
shutting down the platform.
This will solve NPE problems on shutdown.

Created an attachment (id=12421)
Patch to optimize BundleStopper

Since BundleStopper.isStopped() is getting called for every classloader on
shutdown performance of shutdown may be slow without this optimization.
Tom's patch reviewed and included in 4PM build.

JDT is trying to create executable extensions of a plugin that has already been 
stopped:
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.registry.ConfigurationElement.createExecutableExtensio
n(ConfigurationElement.java:113)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.core.JavaCore.getClasspathContainerInitializer
(JavaCore.java:1223)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaModelManager.initializeContainer
(JavaModelManager.java:1245)

My understanding: The class not found exception should be wrapped in a 
CoreException that is handled by JavaCore when it attempts to create an 
executable extension. Plug-is already handle core exceptions when attempting 
to instantiate exceptions, but not runtime exceptions.

Pascal: Is the runtime creating a CoreException or a ClassNotFoundException?

This is exactly what happens. The problem is that osgi and runtime always log
such errors which causes entries in the log although nothing bad happens since
JDT   handles the problem correctly.

Moving back to platform for disposal, since there is nothing wrong in JDTCore.
I would argue that the logging should only be occurring in tracing mode. But 
this is up to platform.

Moving to Equinox for comment/closure. I am assuming that this is wontfix
behaviour as the layer which is logging the messages doesn't know that it is ok
to get them at this point in time.

When we introduced the new exception, we noticed that a lot of things were 
logged. However, we decided to stick with this behavior (which was the 2.1 
behaviour) because if we were not logging and clients of the API relied on us 
to get something in the log, then information would get lost.

So under normal behavior the .log file will grow bigger and bigger?  Are there 
other cases where this happens?

the log will grow. Unfortunately, it is not possible to turn this logging off 
as it is in a very general spot.  We can eliminate one of the log entries but 
it is actually the one that is the most informative.  Post 3.0 we will review 
this but the fix/change is unclear
